scenes.audio_speech: I am proud, but in fact I am very proud to be the first Pashtun, the first Pakistani and the youngest person to receive this award.

scenes.audio_speech: Along with that, along with that, I'm pretty certain that I'm also the first recipient of the Nobel Peace Prize, who still fights with her younger brothers. I want there to be peace everywhere, but my brothers and I are still working on that.
scenes.llm_scene_description: A woman, visible in a consistent position, is speaking at a podium while wearing a pink shawl. She identifies herself as a Nobel Peace Prize recipient who humorously admits to still fighting with her younger brothers, reflecting on her desire for peace globally while still working on it personally.

scenes.audio_speech: just for me. It is for those forgotten children who want education. It is for those frightened children who want peace. It is for those voiceless children who want change. I am here to stand up for their rights, to raise their voice. It is not time to pity them. It is not time to pity them. It is time to take action. So it becomes the last time, the last time. So it becomes the last time that we see a child deprived of education.
scenes.llm_scene_description: A woman is featured prominently delivering a passionate speech, likely at a rally given the presence of other individuals in the initial frame. Throughout the segment, she advocates strongly for children's rights, specifically calling for action to secure their education and peace, and to empower the voiceless, emphasizing that it is "time to take action" rather than pity.

frame_captions: a video frame of a woman in a red dress
a video frame of a woman speaking at a podium
a video frame of a woman in a pink shawr
scenes.audio_speech: I have found that people describe me in many different ways. Some people called me the girl who was shot by the Taliban and some the girl who fought for her rights. Some people called me a noble laureate now. However, my brother still called me that annoying bossy sister. As far as I know, I'm just a committed and even stubborn person who wants to see every child getting quality education, who wants to see women having equal rights and who wants peace in every corner of the world.
scenes.llm_scene_description: A woman is prominently shown speaking at a podium. Visual descriptions note her in a red dress and a pink shawl. In her speech, she identifies herself as a Nobel laureate, articulating her commitment to children's education, women's rights, and world peace.
